Container.Name: Syncthing
Container.Overview: Syncthing replaces proprietary sync and cloud services with something open, trustworthy and decentralized. Your data is your data alone and you deserve to choose where it is stored, if it is shared with some third party and how it's transmitted over the Internet.
Container.Description: Syncthing replaces proprietary sync and cloud services with something open, trustworthy and decentralized. Your data is your data alone and you deserve to choose where it is stored, if it is shared with some third party and how it's transmitted over the Internet.[br][br] [b][span style='color: #E80000;']Directions:[/span][/b][br] [b]/config[/b] : set this path to where you wish Syncthing to store its configuration.[br] [b]/syncfolders[/b] : set this path to folders you wish Syncthing to share/sync.[br][br] [b]Network type:[/b] set to bridge for more secure port mappings, set to host if you need upnp to work.[br] [b]Port number explanations:[/b][br] [b] 8384[/b] - syncthing webgui[br] [b] 22000 and 21027[/b] - syncthing[br] [b] 8443[/b] - discovery server [span style='color: #E80000;'](be sure to add a port map for this if discovery server is enabled)[/span][br] [b] 22067 and 22070[/b] - relay server [span style='color: #E80000;'](be sure to add a port map for these if relay server is enabled)[/span][br] By default, the syncthing service is on while the discovery and relay services are off. This is a default syncthing setup. If you want the discovery and/or relay enabled, see the corresponding environment variables under the advanced settings.[br] discovery documentation: [url]http://docs.syncthing.net/users/discosrv.html[/url][br] relay documentation: [url]http://docs.syncthing.net/users/relaying.html[/url][br]
